Award.AwardTitle: Geometry and Cohomology of Arithmetic and Related Groups
Award.AbstractNarration:
Matrices -- arrays of numbers -- are ubiquitous in science, engineering, and business. The study of the arithmetic governing the behavior of matrices has benefited all these application areas and has also led to advances in several branches of mathematics. This research project aims to advance work that is underway to bundle the equations that represent the algebra of matrices into a single geometric theory, thus allowing techniques from geometry to deepen our understanding of algebra.

This research project aims to study the large-scale geometry, finiteness properties, and cohomological behavior of function-field-arithmetic groups such as the special linear groups SL(n,F[t]) where F is a finite field, and of related groups such as SL(n,Z[t]). Specifically, the principal investigator intends to investigate the cohomology with group ring coefficients of these families of groups. One would also like to understand when groups such as these special linear groups have projective resolutions or classifying complexes with finite skeleta through dimension m, and to determine coefficient modules M and natural numbers m for which the cohomology group of one of these special linear groups in degree m with coefficients in M is infinitely generated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award enabled investigations into geometries, and how transformations of those geometries can shed light onto collections (groups) of matrices, thus allowing algebraic structures to be explored through geometric methods.

The main investigations involve lattices in semisimple groups (particularly semisimple groups over non-Archimedean local fields) -- which are algebraically defined collections of matrices -- and certain related groups, including lattices acting on products of trees and the matrix groups SL(n,Z[t]), where Z[t] are polynomials with integer coefficients. All of these groups and matrices are naturally associated with Euclidean buildings, which are modern geometric objects which reflect some similar properties to those exhibited by Eulcidean spaces. This project included the PI and was also aided by graudate students under the PI's supervision: Hanna Astephan, Matthew Goroff, and Kristen Lee.

The first aspect of the project is an exploration of the concept of semiduality for arithmetic groups defined over global fields of positive characteristic. The concept of semiduality was created in Studenmund-Wortman, precisely to apply to such groups, and to create a previously unobserved analogy with classical arithmetic groups and the concept of duality. Further efforts were made to extend a conjecture that all arithmetic groups defined over function fields experiance semiduality, up to finite-index.

The PI has for many years, and with the help of several others, invesitgated the cohomology of the group SL(n,Z[t]). This work was also continued through the current award, though progress with this group has been slow, which is hitstorically consistent.

The PI thanks the NSF for the opportunities to work on these projects, and for the support that this award has provided.
